2.	Description of Emergency Response

2.1.	Objectives

Emergency response is not just the reaction to incidents and accidents that could pose a threat to personnel, facilities or the environment. As used here, the term also includes the proactive planning that goes into preparing the response to such events. Thus, the objectives of emergency response planning, documentation, and its application are to adequately prepare for and respond to a wide range of potential emergency situations that may be encountered in operating processes and plants that utilize or produce hazardous or toxic materials. These documented preparations allow the facility to have available, and promptly apply, the right kinds of trained manpower and equipment to reduce the effects of such emergency situations.

2.2.	Planning for Emergency Response

The appropriate time to consider how to handle an incident is before it happens. Sound planning begins with the identification of the hazards present in a process or facility and the evaluation of credible incident scenarios, ranging from minor incidents to realistic worst-case situations. The potential incident scenarios may be evaluated using an appropriate method of process hazard analysis (PHA). Next, it is important to gain a perspective on the potential magnitude of the effects of each incident scenario and, perhaps, an appreciation of its likelihood. It is important not to underestimate potential incidents simply because they have never happened or are considered unlikely. a.	INTRODUCTION


i.	Change occurs continually in the chemical industry, and, if not carefully controlled, it can sometimes lead to incidents that could otherwise have been avoided. Change begins in the earliest phases of a project as, for example, in the evaluation of design alternatives. After start­ up, changes are often made to improve the process. ii.	Such changes continue throughout the life of the facility and, as experience has shown, even a small or apparently minor change can have a significant impact on process safety. When making changes, some people may only consider the direct objective of what they want to achieve and may overlook whether the change potentially has some undesired effect on other aspects of the design or operation. Safety reviews, such as Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), and audits can detect these effects. 4.2. Description of Records Management

Records management encompasses both the procedures and the equipment required to effectively handle the PSM record keeping task. Record management systems should be tailored to the individual needs of the facility. Systems can range from a completely manual, paper-based system with file cabinets and manual indexing to a part-less system where all information is entered and all documents are scanned into a computer. Some combination of these two approaches, addressing the operational and economic needs of the facility, can be effective for many users. System choices can be based on various performance requirements, such as speed of retrieval, indexing or search capabilities, or the data storage capacity required. Whether a computer-based system, a manual system, or some combination is used, the system chosen needs to address the potentially conflicting goals of providing information security while, at the same time, providing for ease of dissemination of information to authorized users.
